title: 115_hr3161
content: The Biomass Thermal Utilization Act of 2017, also known as the BTU Act of 2017, includes a Residential Energy-Efficient Property Credit for biomass fuel property expenditures. The BTU Act of 2017 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow a 30 percent credit for qualified biomass fuel property expenditures. This includes property that uses biomass burning. The BTU Act of 2017 allows a 30 percent credit for qualified biomass fuel property expenditures. Biomass fuel property must have a thermal efficiency rating of at least 75 percent and use plant-derived fuel for heating a dwelling unit or water. Biomass fuel includes renewable plant sources like wood, crops, and residues. The BTU Act of 2017 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include qualified biomass fuel property expenditures for a tax credit. The amendments apply to expenditures incurred after December 31, 2016. The BTU Act of 2017 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a tax credit for biomass heating property investments. The BTU Act of 2017 amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a tax credit for biomass heating property investments. Subparagraph (A) of section 48(a)(3) is amended to include open-loop biomass heating property with specific efficiency requirements for boilers or furnaces providing thermal energy for various purposes. The BTU Act of 2017 introduces tax credits for biomass heating property investments, including a 15 percent credit for energy property construction starting before January 1, 2022. The BTU Act of 2017 introduces tax credits for biomass heating property investments, including a credit for energy property with a thermal output efficiency of at least 80 percent, applicable to property construction starting before January 1, 2022. The amendments made by this section apply to periods after December 31, 2016, in taxable years ending after that date, following rules similar to section 48(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
